Resistance to antimalarial drugs has been documented several times over the course of the last 60â€“70 years (
Table 1 ). Chloroquine, discovered in the 1930s, was quickly adopted for widespread treatment and prevention of malaria caused by P. falciparum, Plasmodium vivax, and other species. Resistance of P. falciparum to the drug was first documented in nature in the 1950s, and the effectiveness of chloroquine quickly declined as resistant strains of P. falciparum spread and evolved. Several mechanisms of chloroquine resistance that emerged in nature have been documented in the laboratory, mostly revolving around transport of chloroquine in and out of the parasite. Notably, mutations in a P. falciparum chloroquine resistance transporter gene (PfCRT) have been shown to permit the parasite to efflux chloroquine at a rate 40 times that of cells lacking the mutations ( Martin et al., 2009). Several other mutations of transporter genes have been shown to have a protective effect against the drug, e.g., a chloroquine transporter protein (CG2), and an ATP-binding cassette transporter gene (PfMDR1) ( Haldar et al., 2018).
